items.title: 'We're not going to cancel the games,' Arctic Winter Games organizers say amid Greenland turmoil
items.summary_auto: Excitement for the games among athletes and organizers is growing. But so too are tensions in the circumpolar world, with U.S. President Donald Trump openly musing about a takeover of Greenland.

items.title: Manitoba school bus rollover causes 'significant' injuries, several children taken to hospital, police say
Statistics Canada to trim 850 jobs as public servants, unions brace for more cuts
items.summary_auto: Federal workers are starting to learn more about planned job cuts across the public service after Statistics Canada told employees on Monday that 850 positions will be eliminated from the department over the next two years.

items.title: McDonald's Canada to freeze price of small coffee, drop cost of value meals for one year
items.summary_auto: McDonald's Canada will freeze the price of a small cup of coffee at $1 for at least a year and drop the price of its McValue meals to $5 for the same duration, its CEO announced on Tuesday.

items.title: Canadian automakers warn Carney of ‘extraordinary’ costs they face without EV mandate clarity
items.summary_auto: Three of Canada’s top automotive executives are warning the prime minister that their companies “face extraordinary and unnecessary compliance costs” as a result of his government’s failure to clarify its rules around electric vehicle sales by the end of last year.

items.title: Supreme Court Justice Sheilah Martin to retire, opening up vacancy on bench this spring
items.summary_auto: Justice Sheilah Martin is retiring from the country's highest court, opening up a vacancy on the Supreme Court of Canada bench.

items.title: Staples Canada did not fully wipe personal information from resold laptops, says privacy watchdog
items.summary_auto: The federal privacy watchdog has found Staples Canada did not fully remove personal information from returned laptops that it later resold.

items.title: 'No such thing as a better colonizer': Inuit emphatically reject U.S. takeover of Greenland
items.summary_auto: Inuit advocacy groups, as well as Greenlanders who live in Canada, are emphatically opposed to American designs on their homeland. And, they say, they're tired of being used as a geopolitical chess pieces by powerful people in faraway capitals.

items.title: Saskatoon man charged with inciting hate faces new charge of Holocaust denial
items.summary_auto: Brandon Taylor Moore, who is charged in connection with online comments, was back in Saskatoon provincial court on Tuesday. The Crown added two new charges: wilfully promoting hatred and wilfully promoting antisemitism by condoning, denying or downplaying the Holocaust.

items.title: Olympic champion Guillaume Cizeron accuses ex-ice dance partner of smear campaign
items.summary_auto: Olympic ice dance champion Guillaume Cizeron said Tuesday his former on-ice partner Gabriella Papadakis is spreading lies about him in the lead-up to the Milan-Cortina Winter Games.

items.title: Dilbert creator Scott Adams, whose strip was cancelled over racist remarks, dead at 68
items.summary_auto: Scott Adams, whose popular comic strip Dilbert captured the frustrations of beleaguered, white-collar cubicle workers until he was abruptly dropped from syndication in 2023 for racist remarks, has died.

items.title: Dilbert creator Scott Adams, whose comic strip was cancelled over racist remarks, dead at 68
items.summary_auto: Scott Adams, whose popular comic strip Dilbert captured the frustrations of beleaguered, white-collar cubicle workers until he was abruptly dropped from syndication in 2023 for racist remarks, has died.

items.title: NHL and NHLPA say test events at new Olympic hockey arena were 'good trial run'
items.summary_auto: The NHL and NHL Players' Association said in a joint statement Monday they are pleased test events at the new hockey arena for the Milan-Cortina Olympics were "a good trial run and provided important insight into the current status" of construction.

items.title: Central bank heads, including Canada's, defend U.S. Fed chair Powell
items.summary_auto: Leaders of central banks from around the world, including Canada's Tiff Macklem, have lined up in support of U.S. Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, issuing an unprecedented statement of solidarity after the Trump administration threatened him with a criminal indictment.

items.title: Chinese-language paper Ming Pao closing down B.C., Ontario offices, laying off 60 staff
items.summary_auto: The newspaper, which has newsrooms in Richmond, B.C., and Toronto, Ont., is winding up its Canadian operations due to financial reasons, says a letter from the publisher.

items.title: Russian attacks in Ukraine kill 4 as U.S. rebukes Moscow for 'escalation' amid peace talks
items.summary_auto: Russia launched a second major drone and missile bombardment of Ukraine in four days, officials said Tuesday, aiming again at the power grid amid freezing temperatures in an apparent snub to U.S.-led peace efforts as Moscow's invasion of its neighbour approaches the four-year mark.

items.title: Prospective mom accused of killing boy, torturing brother testifies about damage to children's bedrooms
Trump ends temporary protected status for Somalis living in U.S.
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump's administration will end humanitarian protections that grant deportation relief and work permits to some 1,100 Somalis in the U.S., administration officials said on Tuesday, the latest restrictive move targeting Somali immigrants.

items.title: At least 6 dead across Gaza as rainstorm sweeps away tents, exposes children to cold
items.summary_auto: A rainstorm swept across the Gaza Strip on Tuesday, flooding hundreds of tents, collapsing homes sheltering families displaced by two years of war and killing at least six people, local health officials said.

items.title: Rescue dog found after 54 days in wilderness on Vancouver's North Shore
items.summary_auto: A rescue dog was found in Metro Vancouver's North Shore after being lost in the wilderness for 54 days, after an outpouring of support from the local community and concerted efforts from searchers.

items.title: Arson suspect in attack on historic Mississippi synagogue admitted to antisemitic motive, FBI alleges
items.summary_auto: A suspect in an arson fire at a synagogue that was bombed by the Ku Klux Klan decades ago admitted to targeting the historic institution because it's a Jewish house of worship and confessed what he had done to his father, who turned him in to authorities after observing burn marks on his son's ankles, hands and face, the FBI said Monday.

items.title: Manitoba civil servants won't be ordered to office full-time like their Ontario, Alberta counterparts
items.summary_auto: Manitoba Premier Wab Kinew said his government will continue allowing remote work for many public servants. The current policy for full-time employees is at least three days in the workplace every week.

items.title: Millions of temporary residents will have to leave Canada when their permits expire. But will they?
Palestinian students accepted into Canadian universities remain ‘trapped’ in Gaza by visa delays
items.summary_auto: Biometrics  — fingerprints and photographs required for Canadian visas — can only be collected outside Gaza, typically in Egypt or the West Bank.

items.title: Who was Trevor Dubois? Loved ones want people to understand the man they knew
items.summary_auto: Trevor Dubois is being remembered by friends and family as a man defined by laughter, compassion and advocacy. Those closest to him describe an outgoing, flamboyant and deeply kind man who was known for helping Indigenous youth and others struggling with mental health in Saskatchewan.

items.title: 2.1 million temporary residents will have expired or expiring permits this year. But will they leave Canada?
items.summary_auto: Ottawa says 2.1 million temporary residents will have expired or expiring permits this year. But experts say some will consider going underground and undocumented.

items.title: Kitchener, Ont., woman looking for stranger who helped family say one last goodbye to her stepdad
items.summary_auto: A family from Kitchener, Ont., wants to find and say thank you to a Good Samaritan who gave their loved one CPR, extending his life until paramedics arrived on the scene, transported him to hospital and gave his family a chance to say one last goodbye.

items.title: ‘It’s heartbreaking’: Royal Canadian Legion closes 99-year-old Halifax branch
items.summary_auto: The Vimy legion branch was closed on Friday night after a meeting with officials from Nova Scotia/Nunavut Command, which is responsible for all branches in the province.

items.title: Iranian protest deaths estimated at over 2,000, larger than in any recent unrest in country
items.summary_auto: The death toll from nationwide protests in Iran spiked Tuesday to at least 2,000 people killed, activists said, as Iranians made phone calls abroad for the first time in days after authorities severed communications during a crackdown.

items.title: ‘Frequent flyers’ behind surge in violence on public transit
We started drinking more during the pandemic — and that habit hasn't changed much, a new survey finds
items.summary_auto: Many people are starting 2026 by taking part in Dry January, swearing off alcohol for the first month of the year. But new research from the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH) is raising concerns about how much Canadians are drinking.

items.title: Overcrowding at Niagara jail reaches 6-year peak, with 40% more inmates since 2019
items.summary_auto: The Niagara correction workers union president says employees struggle to provide programming as jail population increases and the mother of son who died at the detention centre said he had been sleeping on mattresses of his cell's floor.

items.title: Police officers with PTSD in this Ontario region say their force fights against workplace benefits
U.S., NATO have long history of not being serious about Greenland. That's about to change
items.summary_auto: NATO is talking about improved Arctic security, says the alliance's secretary general. Some of those talks reportedly involve a European troop presence in Greenland. It's a remarkable turnaround for an alliance that has until recently tried to ignore the region.

items.title: No Name beef burgers recalled due to risk of E. coli
items.summary_auto: No Name brand frozen beef burgers that were sold across the country are being recalled due to a risk of E. coli contamination.

items.title: Can diplomacy stop Trump's plans for Greenland?
items.summary_auto: Tensions have grown between Washington, Denmark and Greenland this month as U.S. President Donald Trump and his administration have continued to push the narrative that Greenland should belong to the U.S. They've led to a flurry of meetings and talks this week.

items.title: B.C. Court of Appeal sides with Purolator after COVID-19 vaccine mandate led to hundreds of firings
items.summary_auto: The B.C. Court of Appeal has set aside the decision of a labour administrator who found in favour of Purolator employees who were fired for not getting the COVID-19 vaccine.

items.title: U.S. tells its citizens to leave Iran, as Trump pressures Tehran over protest crackdown
items.summary_auto: The United States is telling its citizens to leave Iran, as Washington maintains its pressure on Tehran to cease its crackdown on protesters and U.S. President Donald Trump threatens to strike the Iranian government over the issue
